text: In our previous study , we demonstrated that <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is recruited to the CD40 signaling complex in two mouse B cell lines [ 6 ] .

Similar results were obtained with mouse splenocytes , indicating that the interaction of <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> with <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is not limited to transformed B cell lines ( unpublished observations ) .

text: We also found that the recruitment of <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was <extra_id_0> TRAF2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent and that overexpression of a truncated <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutant partially inhibited <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated NF-kappaB activation .

text: These results support the hypothesis that <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> plays a role in <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signal transduction .

To further define the role and evaluate the importance of <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling , we used somatic cell gene targeting to disrupt the gene encoding <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the mouse B cell line A20.2J .

This cell line has been particularly useful in the characterization of <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling mechanisms due to the relative ease with which its genome can be modified by homologous recombination [ 7 ] , [ 8 ] , [ 9 ] .

We used a targeting vector capable of undergoing homologous recombination with <extra_id_0> Rnf31 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( the gene encoding <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) to disrupt the coding sequence of the gene in exon 5 ( Fig . 1A ) .

Following introduction of the vector , the neomycin - resistant clones that arose were screened by PCR amplification of genomic DNA to identify cells containing a disrupted <extra_id_0> Rnf31 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> allele .

To remove the selectable marker gene cassette from the disrupted <extra_id_0> Rnf31 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> allele , recombinant cell lines were transiently transfected with a plasmid that encodes <extra_id_0> Cre recombinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
This step allowed us to perform a second round of targeting and drug selection , generating cells in which both copies of <extra_id_0> Rnf31 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> were disrupted .
Two independent clonal cell lines were chosen for further analysis .

<extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein expression was undetectable in both cell lines , as determined by Western blot analysis of cell lysates ( Fig . 1B ) , demonstrating that the targeting process was successful .
In the text that follows , the two gene - targeted cell lines are referred to as <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient cells .

To enable us to confirm that any signaling or functional defects observed in <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient cells were due to disruption of the <extra_id_0> Rnf31 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene , both <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient cell lines were transduced with a retrovirus encoding FLAG-tagged wild-type <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , thus restoring <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein expression ( Fig . 1B ) .

text: These cells are referred to as <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - reconstituted cells .

In the experiments that follow , responses by these cells were compared to those of A20.2J cells and <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient cells transduced with a retroviral vector ( pMIP ) lacking a cDNA insert ( empty vector ) .
